startups<\/h2>\n "attachment_2619340\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619340\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2619340\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> anyaberkut \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n When you think of successful business models, obviously B2B SaaS and internet advertising come to mind. And if your company lands in one of those two areas, you know the formula for profitability.<\/p>\n There is another model, though, called \u201ccapturing spread,\u201d which is taking in a small amount of revenue on a bigger flow of capital. It\u2019s not as profitable, but it could be the right move for your startup.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"wJtiv0SoI1\"> subscribe<\/a><\/strong><\/h3>\n Deal Dive: Bagels with a schmear of venture capital<\/h2>\n "attachment_2621267\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2621267\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2621267\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/JenGoldbergManyBagels.jpg\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Jen Goldberg<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Popup Bagels recently raised an $8 million Series A, which had TC+\u2019s venture reporter \u2014 and self-proclaimed bagel snob \u2014 Rebecca Szkutak raise her eyebrows. After all, shouldn\u2019t a mom-and-pop bagel shop qualify for a small business loan? But what makes Popup seem more like a venture-backable business is its focus and lean operations. Oh, Becca reports that the bagels are pretty good, too!<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Wr29FgyHNQ\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/28\/deal-dive-bagels-with-a-schmear-of-venture-capital\/\">Deal Dive: Bagels with a schmear of venture capital<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n Pitch Deck Teardown: Aether\u2019s $49M Series A deck<\/h2>\n "attachment_2619350\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> "https:\/\/www.aetherbio.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Aether "screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a><\/p><\/div><\/p>\n \u201cAether\u2019s pitch deck is a real head-scratcher,\u201d writes pitch deck expert Haje Jan Kamps. Though it got a few things right, there are a couple places where it could improve. For example, Haje points out that it was \u201cthe worst \u2018use of funds\u2019 slide\u201d he\u2019s seen in years. It\u2019s also missing a team slide. So how\u2019d the company raise almost $50 million?<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"gi0v9ChKYz\"> inal-questions\/","title":{"rendered":"SBF\u2019s defense puts forth a 35-minute last-ditch effort to show his goodwill"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">As Sam Bankman-Fried<\/span> took the stand for the last time in his trial for fraud and money laundering, his main lawyer, Mark Cohen, returned to question him on a number of themes that prosecutors touched on in the past few days. But this time, he took a different approach, presenting the defendant as a person who was acting in good faith.<\/p>\n \u201cWe lived and died by having a better product than competitors,\u201d Bankman-Fried said of his "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/11\/ftx-files-for-bankruptcy-ceo-sam-bankman-fried-steps-down\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">now-bankrupt crypto exchange<\/a>, FTX. Bankman-Fried owned majority stakes in both FTX and its sister trading firm, Alameda Research, but insisted he wanted the best for both.<\/p>\n Bankman-Fried has been "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/sam-bankman-fried-takes-the-stand\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">testifying since Thursday afternoon<\/a>, and the prosecution has grilled him for the past few days as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/sam-bankman-fried-ftx-cross-examination\/\">part of their cross-examination<\/a>. On Tuesday, when the defense lawyers returned to reexamine him, he was swaying slightly on the stand, shoulders drawn down and forward. He spoke softly, but was more talkative than earlier in the day and on Monday when he was being questioned.<\/p>\n Contrary to the picture prosecutors tried to paint, Bankman-Fried insisted that he was not involved in the day-to-day trading operations of Alameda or its \u201ccore operations,\u201d but instead emphasized his concern for its leadership at the time, saying he wanted to be involved in many of its venture investments, decisions on hedging, and other areas.

She previously was a crypto reporter for Blockworks covering decentralized finance, DAOs and crypto venture capital funding and prior to that covered energy markets for S&P Global Platts and Bloomberg News. Her articles are published in over 70 news outlets and she graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a degree in Media and Journalism and a minor in creative writing. Disclosure: Jacquelyn owns various cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin and Ethereum. She does not day trade cryptocurrencies, NFTs or any other crypto-related products. October Scary Fast Event: Everything revealed about the new MacBook Pro, iMac and M3 chips"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "font-weight: 400;\">Apple\u2019s October event had some exciting product announcements \u2014 but don\u2019t worry, there was nothing too spooky. Last week, the company <\/span> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/apple-sends-out-invites-for-scary-fast-event-new-macs-could-be-on-the-way\/\"> "font-weight: 400;\">announced a surprise \u201cScary Fast\u201d event<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">, prompting speculation that Apple would reveal new chips to power a new lineup of Macs.<\/span><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-scary-fast-mac-event-how-to-watch-and-what-to-expect\/\"> "font-weight: 400;\">As our resident Apple expert Brian Heater wrote<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">, a <\/span> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-m3-imac-is-up-for-pre-order-starting-at-1299\/\"> "font-weight: 400;\">new 24-inch iMac<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\"> and a <\/span> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-14-and-16-inch-m3-macbook-pros-arrive-in-space-black-color-starting-at-1599\/\"> "font-weight: 400;\">MacBook Pro refresh<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\"> would be the most likely new announcements to expect from the October event, and he was exactly right. Apple\u2019s new M3 chip lineup was the focal point of the event, powering each of the devices Apple showcased in their half-hour prerecorded event that had some seasonally appropriate fog, bats and ominous choir music\u2026but no big surprises for those closely following the rumor mill.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The event kicked off at the uncharacteristically late time of 8pm ET \/ 5pm PT, so you might have missed out on the reveals while putting the finishing touches on your Halloween decorating or watching Monday Night Football. No judgment; we\u2019ve put together everything that was revealed at the event all in one spot.<\/span><\/p>\n New M3 chips<\/h2>\n "attachment_2622215\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2622215\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2622215\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"Apple M3 Chips\" width=\"680\" height=\"362\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png 1520w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=150,80 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=300,160 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=768,409 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=680,362 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=1200,639 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.05.52-PM.png?resize=50,27 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2622215\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Credit:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The “scary fast” part of the Apple event, as expected, are the new M3 chips. Apple has announced M3, M3 Pro and M3 Max, which will be included in Apple’s new 24-inch iMac and MacBook Pros.<\/p>\n This time around, Apple has placed an emphasis on graphical horsepower, with hardware-accelerated ray tracing, mesh shading and Dynamic Caching, which Apple claims “dramatically increases the average utilization of the GPU” by allotting the exact amount of local memory to given tasks. These new chips were frequently benchmarked against their M1 predecessor, with Apple claiming the M3 renders at 2.5x the speed of the M1 and its CPU is 30% faster than the M1.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-m3-m3-pro-and-m3-max-3-nanometer-chips-arrive-with-a-big-graphics-boost\/\">Check out the full rundown of the three M3 chips right here.<\/a><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n New MacBook Pro models<\/h2>\n "attachment_2622225\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2622225\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2622225\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"Apple MacBook Pro 2023 Update in Space Black Color\" width=\"680\" height=\"385\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png 1496w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=150,85 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=300,170 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=768,434 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=680,385 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=1200,679 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.20.46-PM.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2622225\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Credit:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Yes, the new 14-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pros come with upgraded internals, but the first thing you might notice is the new color: Space Black. Beneath that color, you’ll find that new line of M3 chips. The 14-inch MacBook Pro can contain any of the trio, while the 16-inch model will only come with the M3 Pro or M3 Max chips.<\/p>\n As we’ve noted, the M3 chips packed into both models are putting an emphasis on getting the most out of the new GPU, though Apple also boasts that both form factors’ battery can last 22 hours on a single charge.<\/p>\n Both are available for preorder tonight, with the 14-inch MacBook Pro starting at $1,599 and going to $1,999 with the M3 Pro. The baseline 16-inch MacBook Pro goes for $2,499 and the pricing for the M3 Max chip upgrade for both models has yet to be disclosed.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apple-brought-back-the-best-mac-colorway-with-the-new-m3-macbook-pro\/\">And that space black color is exciting news for any Mac fan still pining for the 2006 MacBook<\/a>, whose dark tone hadn’t been replicated in the MacBook iterations that followed, even those Midnight MacBook Airs.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-14-and-16-inch-m3-macbook-pros-arrive-in-space-black-color-starting-at-1599\/\">Check out the full rundown on the new MacBook Pros here.<\/a><\/p>\n New M3 iMac<\/h2>\n "attachment_2622238\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2622238\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2622238\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"2023 M3 iMac Spec Rundown\" width=\"680\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png 1530w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=300,168 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=768,431 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=680,381 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=1200,673 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-30-at-5.28.21-PM.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2622238\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Credit:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Apple’s iMac line is getting a colorful refresh, with an added M3 chip to add horsepower to the palette change. Apple is sticking with the 24-inch form factor, and upgrading the screen with a 4.5K retina display, 1080p FaceTime camera and a six-speaker system supporting Dolby Atmos and Spatial Audio. The new iMac will be available for preorder with green, yellow, orange, pink, purple, blue and silver options starting tonight.<\/p>\n The $1,299 baseline comes with an 8-core GPU and 8-core CPU, with a $1,499 version upgrading you to a 256 SSD.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-m3-imac-is-up-for-pre-order-starting-at-1299\/\">For more info about what else is new in the M3 iMac, head here<\/a>.<\/p>\n Farewell to the Touch Bar<\/b><\/h2>\n "attachment_1408077\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-1408077\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-1408077\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Apple's Discontinued Touch Bar in its First Reveal\" width=\"680\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg 1822w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=300,168 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=768,429 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=680,380 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=1536,858 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=1200,670 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2016\/10\/tabs-safari-touch-bar.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-1408077\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Credit:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The new line of MacBook Pros <\/span> "https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/apple-finally-kills-off-the-13-inch-touch-bar-macbook-pro-004008890.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">marks the end of the Touch Bar<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">, which never really found its footing. The announcement of the new 14-inch MacBook Pro effectively replaces the 13-inch MacBook Pro, the last Apple product to carry the Touch Bar keyboard after the company released 14-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pros in 2021 without it. <\/span><\/p>\n A sneaky iPhone showcase<\/h2>\n You may not have noticed it, but at the very end of the event, Apple dropped a quick note on the stream: “This event was shot on iPhone and edited on Mac.” It’s a bit of a victory lap, but "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/apples-scary-fast-event-video-was-shot-on-iphone\/\">as our other Apple expert Darrell Etherington notes<\/a>, it’s a pretty impressive flex for Apple to shoot its half-hour hardware showcase entirely on a phone.<\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Apple posted a video after the reveals solely about its production process for the October event.<\/span><\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/V3dbG9pAi8I?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n Recap the full Scary Fast event<\/h2>\n If you want to just dive right in and experience the October event all over again or for the first time, you can catch the entire archive via the YouTube embed below "https:\/\/www.apple.com\/apple-events\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">right on Apple’s website<\/a>.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/ctkW3V0Mh-k?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Apple\u2019s October event had some exciting product announcements \u2014 but don\u2019t worry, there was nothing too spooky. Last week, the company announced a surprise \u201cScary Fast\u201d event, prompting speculation that Apple would reveal new chips to power a new lineup of Macs. As our resident Apple expert Brian Heater wrote, a new 24-inch iMac and TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-event-october-2023\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-event-october-2023\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-event-october-2023\/","name":"Apple October 2023 on TechCrunch","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-event-october-2023\/#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"BreadcrumbList","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/apple-event-october-2023\/#breadcrumb","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Apple Event October 2023"}]},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577202450"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577202450"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577202450"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577202450"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577202450"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577202450"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622437,"date":"2023-10-31T10:21:47","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T17:21:47","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622437"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:34:48","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:34:48","slug":"alexis-ohanian-says-hes-a-techno-optimist-despite-social-medias-impact-on-society","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/alexis-ohanian-says-hes-a-techno-optimist-despite-social-medias-impact-on-society\/","title":{"rendered":"Alexis Ohanian says he’s a ‘techno optimist,’ despite social media’s impact on society"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Does Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian have regrets over his creation? The entrepreneur and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/01\/reddit-co-founder-alexis-ohanians-776-closes-new-500m-venture-fund\/\"> founder of venture fund Seven Seven Six<\/a>, speaking at an event at the University of Virginia, espoused a fairly negative view of the current social media landscape and the creator economy — an environment where he says, everyone has “been so trained and conditioned now to just get the likes and retweets, get the upvotes…I wish I could be more optimistic about it, but we’re seeing it play out before our eyes.” Still, he ultimately described himself as a “techno-optimist” — an apparent nod to a16z General Partner "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/when-was-the-last-time-marc-andreessen-talked-to-a-poor-person\/\">Marc Andreessen’s recent diatribe<\/a> where he claimed technology could solve all our problems.<\/p>\n “Guilty as charged,” Ohanian said, during his "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=NE7Vd546mLM\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">interview<\/a> with Kara Swisher. “I do think that pendulum will swing back. I think even swifter than we realize.” The war in the Middle East may even be the tipping point, he theorized, as it’s now “abundantly clear” that we need something better to figure out the world than the platforms we have today.<\/p>\n The founder, as you may recall, notably "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/05\/alexis-ohanian-steps-down-reddit-board\/\">resigned from Reddit’s board in 2020<\/a> over differences of opinion on moderation and wanting to crack down on communities about violence and hate. It was a moment where he seemed to be reckoning with what his platform had wrought. At the time, he asked for his board seat to be replaced by a Black board member. The company agreed, appointing its first Black board member "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/10\/reddit-names-ycs-michael-seibel-to-board-following-co-founder-alexis-ohanians-exit\/\">with Y Combinator partner Michael Seibel<\/a>.<\/p>\n Reddit also later banned several toxic communities, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/08\/reddit-donaldtrump-ban-capitol\/\">including r\/donaldtrup<\/a> following violence at the U.S. Capitol, and Ohanian says that the site has “gotten demonstrably better,” since, as well as better as a business.<\/p>\n But as for social media as a whole, of which Reddit would presumably play a part, Ohanian said it brings out the “worst parts of our nature in many ways.” What’s more, he expressed worries about the desire for people to be first and win on whatever leaderboard a platform features, which then leads to a situation where misinformation is able to spread.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">Humans evolved trusting the faces & voices we knew around the campfire. The idea of believing something bc of experts\/institutions you've never met is actually new to our species.<\/p>\n I visited "https:\/\/twitter.com\/UVADemocracy?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@UVADemocracy<\/a> + chatted with "https:\/\/twitter.com\/karaswisher?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@karaswisher<\/a> + "https:\/\/twitter.com\/dkroy?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@dkroy<\/a> about what's next for social media.
"https:\/\/t.co\/PMBXi7T3vv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/PMBXi7T3vv<\/a><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n — Alexis Ohanian \ud83c\udde6\ud83c\uddf2 (@alexisohanian) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/alexisohanian\/status\/1719373075295199280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 31, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n “Now, there’s so much pressure to be first, and UGC — user-generated content — will always win. It won’t always be right, though. But it becomes the epicenter of where the conversation is. And then I’ll think what percentage of our population really wants to earnestly take the breath and say, let me stop doomscrolling, and let me just wait until people can do the work, synthesize it and then help me react?” he continued.<\/p>\n “We are also so plugged into all these storylines, whether it’s from traditional media, whether it’s from user-generated — someone on their phone, you know, posting to a Telegram group. We are overwhelmed and overloaded, and it’s unfortunately appealing to the worst parts of a lot of our instincts,” Ohanian added.<\/p>\n In part, some of the issues around how social media platforms developed had to do with how the companies were originally developed. Ohanian, for example, shared that Reddit grew out of his running of a forum site in college, when he believed that online community felt as real as offline. He said he never conceived of the influence the site would one day hold — when Reddit became a multibillion-dollar business with hundreds of millions of users. That thought would have been “ludicrous,” he said. And he certainly never could have imagined his startup could have become so successful that it could affect elections and democracies.<\/p>\n “To… think Oh my god, I’m gonna be so successful, it could have a tremendous impact on democracy would take a level of delusion that even I, as a first-time CEO, just couldn’t have,” he noted. “Was that a blind spot? Absolutely,” he admitted.<\/p>\n Ohanian identified that another part of the problem is that there are more people online today than early tech founders may have imagined. Though he’s glad that access to the technology has broadened, that has come with many complications.<\/p>\n “I don’t like the idea that the internet I’m so nostalgic for was actually an ivory tower,” he said, but on the flip side, he said, we’re all exposed to more people, in real-time, than we could have ever fathomed. And that can put people at odds with one another and with everyone’s different versions of the truth — even if their truth is believing in something as far-fetched as the earth being flat, he said, pointing to one example that has a following on Reddit.<\/p>\n Meanwhile, asking platforms like Facebook, Twitter, or Reddit to be in charge of verifying truth and accuracy is a difficult task, he said. Ohanian also called out TikTok as “an arm for the Chinese government” that’s really good at “feeding us what we want, when we want it” — in other words, not always a fountain of truth, either.<\/p>\n If anything, Ohanian credits Twitter (now called X) with coming up with the best system for moderation so far.<\/p>\n “Community Notes, I personally think is a good — it’s the best measure I’ve seen yet. And frankly, I wish we had thought of it first,” he said.<\/p>\n Still, he called out the notion that a platform, like X, can be a town square.<\/p>\n “The public square [analogy]…falls flat. Because if that then implies that it’s a public square, which means like, what? a town or a city? If you’re the person in charge of it, you’re the mayor. But there’s no democratic election,” Ohanian pointed out. “You’re a CEO. So then you’re like the king? If you want to lean into the town square thing, fine. Just own it and say, yeah, it’s a town square and I am the infinite dictator, tyrant of it.”<\/p>\n Despite the problems with social media and the urgency, in terms of its impact on society, Ohanian believes there’s still some hope. He noted, for example, that the founders "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/01\/reddit-co-founder-alexis-ohanians-776-closes-new-500m-venture-fund\/\">his fund 776 invests in<\/a> are much smarter and more aware of the issues than he ever was at their age. Perhaps the next platforms will still be addictive, but in a way that doesn’t “further disrupt democracy,” he mused.<\/p>\n He also believes that after everything on social media becomes so perfectly curated for us, our brains will start to crave things that are not. “I think we’ll see a rebirth of live gatherings and in-person experiences…the bright side of this is that I hope it then gets us back in touch with our humanity, and the things that no amount of AI can replace.”<\/p>\n “I want to be an optimist about it,” Ohanian added. “And I think there’s still a path forward but we’re fighting against very, very strong human things. And if we can solve it, it will do so much good. It really, really will because we will find out we have more in common than not,” he said.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Does Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian have regrets over his creation? The entrepreneur and founder of venture fund Seven Seven Six, speaking at an event at the University of Virginia, espoused a fairly negative view of the current social media landscape and the creator economy — an environment where he says, everyone has “been so trained […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2622493,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"d5073142-839f-3f7e-9c43-caac22c72265","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-31T17:21:54Z","apple_news_api_id":"3c80d931-8a70-489d-8b06-284cd75d3476","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-31T21:34:40Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/APIDZMYpwSJ2LBihM1100dg","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593,20429],"tags":[174200,1098,22,40179,49818,620,577199626],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Alexis Ohanian says he's a 'techno optimist,' despite social media's impact on society | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"Does Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian have regrets over his creation? The entrepreneur and founder of venture fund Seven Seven Six, speaking at an event","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/alexis-ohanian-says-hes-a-techno-optimist-despite-social-medias-impact-on-society\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"Alexis Ohanian says he's a 'techno optimist,' despite social media's impact on society | TechCrunch","og_description":"Does Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian have regrets over his creation? The entrepreneur and founder of venture fund Seven Seven Six, speaking at an event","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/alexis-ohanian-says-hes-a-techno-optimist-despite-social-medias-impact-on-society\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","article_publisher":"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","article_published_time":"2023-10-31T17:21:47+00:00","article_modified_time":"2023-10-31T21:34:48+00:00","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":611,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/alexis-ohanian-uva.jpg?resize=1200,611","type":"image\/jpeg"}],"author":"Sarah Perez","twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_creator":"@TechCrunch","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","twitter_misc":{"Written by":"Sarah Perez","Est. reading time":"5 Prior to her work as a reporter, Sarah worked in I.T. across a number of industries, including banking, retail and name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577199626"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577199626"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577199626"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577199626"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577199626"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577199626"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622446,"date":"2023-10-31T09:38:33","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T16:38:33","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622446"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:20:53","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:20:53","slug":"toyota-to-invest-another-8b-into-north-carolina-ev-battery-factory","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/toyota-to-invest-another-8b-into-north-carolina-ev-battery-factory\/","title":{"rendered":"Toyota to invest another $8B into North Carolina EV battery factory"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Toyota said Tuesday it will invest another $8 billion into its first EV battery factory in North America, as the Japanese automaker tries to ramp up its electrification program and introduce 30 battery electric models globally by the end of the decade.<\/p>\n The North Carolina-based factory, which is slated to go into production in 2025, is now valued at $13.9 billion, according to the company. That’s a jump from Toyota’s initial plans to make a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/10\/18\/toyota-earmarks-3-4-billion-to-boost-ev-battery-production-in-the-u-s-through-2030\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$1.29 billion investment<\/a> to build a North American factory that will make batteries for hybrid electric vehicles and battery electric vehicles.<\/p>\n This latest investment will add eight battery electric and plug-in hybrid battery production lines to the facility located on 1,825 acres in Liberty, North Carolina. Once completed, the factory will have 10 lines and will reach a total production capacity of 30 GWh annually by 2030. To put that into perspective, the so-called Tesla gigafactory, which is a joint venture between the automaker and Panasonic, has the capacity to make 35 GWh of cells annually.<\/p>\n Toyota was long seen as a laggard in its commitment to moving its entire lineup to battery electric. The automaker, which has more recently ramped up its EV program, still stands by its approach to produce and sell a mix of hybrid, plug-in hybrid and battery electric vehicles.<\/p>\n Toyota’s expansion plans come as other automakers tap the brakes on EVs. Ford and GM, both of which have made ambitious targets to convert most of their portfolios to all-electric vehicles, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/29\/ford-gm-ev-uncertainty\/#:~:text=Ford%20and%20GM%20executives%20have,%2436%2C000%20per%20EV%20last%20quarter.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">have tempered plans<\/a> as demand for premium EVs has waned. These companies are still developing next-generation EVs, but have either delayed battery factory plans or the roll out of new EV models. Last week, Ford said it was delaying about "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/ford-delays-12b-in-ev-investments-as-automaker-wrestles-with-demand\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$12 billion in EV-related investments<\/a>.<\/p>\n Still, the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/16\/tracking-the-ev-battery-factory-construction-boom-across-north-america\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">EV factory boom<\/a> is still chugging along, particularly in the so-called battery belt that stretches from Michigan down to South Carolina.<\/p>\n North Carolina has become a hotspot for EV battery factories and other facilities related to EVs. More than $11 billion has been invested in the EV industry in the state since 2020, including a $2 billion investment from Vietnamese auto manufacturer VinFast and Wolfspeed’s plan to build a $5 billion semiconductor manufacturing plant.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n The Toyota plant is expected to employ more than 5,000 people, according to the Economic Development Partnership of North Carolina.<\/p>\n “Today’s announcement is yet another validation of North Carolina’s national recognition as a hub for innovation, and a top location for electric vehicle manufacturers and suppliers,” said Christopher Chung, CEO at the Economic Development Partnership of North Carolina. “Japanese investment has a significant impact in our state, with more than 28,000 North Carolinians going to work for Japanese companies every day. We value and appreciate the ongoing partnership our state has with Japan and the economic impact this partnership will continue to have.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Toyota said Tuesday it will invest another $8 billion into its first EV battery factory in North America, as the Japanese automaker tries to ramp up its electrification program and introduce 30 battery electric models globally by the end of the decade. The North Carolina-based factory, which is slated to go into production in 2025, name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/13804"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=13804"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=13804"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=13804"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=13804"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=13804"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2621963,"date":"2023-10-31T09:00:18","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T16:00:18","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2621963"},"modified":"2023-10-30T15:46:45","modified_gmt":"2023-10-30T22:46:45","slug":"this-new-startup-aims-to-help-businesses-like-chick-fil-a-get-construction-permits-in-weeks","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/this-new-startup-aims-to-help-businesses-like-chick-fil-a-get-construction-permits-in-weeks\/","title":{"rendered":"GreenLite streamlines ‘nightmare’ of construction permitting for businesses"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "font-weight: 400;\">Getting the required permits for construction can take an excruciatingly long time in many cities — whether it\u2019s for a residential or commercial project.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">One new proptech startup is out to make the process much less painful — and faster — for businesses, and has already landed several large customers such as Chick-fil-A, Domino\u2019s and Chipotle. For businesses like these, time is money. So the faster they can get up and running, obviously the more revenue they can generate.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">That startup — Austin-based <\/span> "https:\/\/www.greenlite.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">GreenLite<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\"> — is emerging from stealth today with $8 million in seed funding led by <\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">Trust Ventures with participation from LiveOak Ventures and Chicago Ventures.<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\"> The company claims that its platform accelerates permit approval for city planning by 75% — so that businesses can get permits in a matter of weeks, as opposed to months, or in the worst cases, years.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">CEO and co-founder James Gallagher said GreenLite has built software that allows it to \u201cown\u201d the permitting process from start to finish so that it can more accurately predict opening dates and directly respond to comments during plan review. Its platform and team connects developers that want to build and the city agencies that regulate and review construction permits.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">\u201cOther companies in the space only service one side – the developer or the city agency – and they have focused on building project management software for either of those sides,\u201d he told TechCrunch via email. <\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">\u201c<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">Other companies in the space also have focused on enhancing the permit expediting process, which leverages a local middle-man or consulting firm to facilitate permitting. We aren\u2019t interested in expediting as we don\u2019t consider it scalable.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Gallagher, a former Gopuff executive, added: \u201cWe believe that building one platform that serves all stakeholders on both sides is crucial to solve this problem. If information lives in silos and everyone involved can\u2019t collaborate seamlessly, the permitting process breaks down.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Besides the large food chain customers it is working with, GreenLite says it works with hundreds of businesses, including five of the top 10 largest global retailers, massive franchises and EV charging networks.\u00a0<\/span><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Chick-fil-A in particular had experienced construction permitting timelines that ranged from six-12 months. GreenLite claims it was able to drive construction permitting timelines to weeks.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Founded in July 2022, GreenLite has managed to gain so much traction in a short period of time, Gallagher believes, because the \u201c<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">pain is high and problem is real and expensive – so there’s lots of demand.\u201d He declined to share any specifics around revenue or financials, or the company\u2019s valuation.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">He said the 27-person company is planning to use its new capital to grow its go-to-market (sales and customer success) team, expand its product and engineering team and increase its presence in new markets.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Currently, while GreenLite says it <\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">supports its customers nationwide, it has a particular focus on Florida and Texas. With the new capital, it will aim to boost its presence in New Jersey, Virginia, Tennessee and California.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Sal Churi, general partner at Trust Ventures, described permitting as a \u201cnightmare.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">\u201cIt\u2019s the biggest gating item to building and it\u2019s completely outside of your control. Today permitting means confusing requirements, unexpected delays leading to cost overruns, and zero visibility into the timeline,\u201d he wrote via email. \u201cWe invested in GreenLite because their team understands this challenge firsthand. The product gets customers permits in a third of the time, in some cases saving over a million dollars in lost revenue, and increasing transparency. It\u2019s a game changer for architects, engineers, and entrepreneurs.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Getting the required permits for construction can take an excruciatingly long time in many cities — whether it\u2019s for a residential or commercial project. One new proptech startup is out to make the process much less painful — and faster — for businesses, and has already landed several large customers such as Chick-fil-A, Domino\u2019s and crunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/deepminds-latest-alphafold-model-is-more-useful-for-drug-discovery\/","title":{"rendered":"DeepMind’s latest AlphaFold model is more useful for drug discovery"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Nearly five years ago, DeepMind, one of Google’s more prolific AI-centered research labs, debuted "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/alphafold\/\">AlphaFold<\/a>, an AI system that can accurately predict the structures of many proteins inside the human body. Since then, DeepMind has improved on the system, releasing an updated and more capable version of AlphaFold — "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/22\/deepmind-puts-the-entire-human-proteome-online-as-folded-by-alphafold\/\">AlphaFold 2<\/a> — in 2020.<\/p>\n And the lab’s work continues.<\/p>\n Today, DeepMind revealed that the newest release of AlphaFold, the successor to AlphaFold 2, can generate predictions for nearly all molecules in the Protein Data Bank, the world’s largest open access database of biological molecules.<\/p>\n Already, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/04\/isomorphic-labs-is-alphabets-play-in-ai-drug-discovery\/#:~:text=The%20field%20of%20drug%20discovery,into%20a%20tractable%20information%20problem.\">Isomorphic Labs<\/a>, a spin-off of DeepMind focused on drug discovery, is applying the new AlphaFold model — which it co-designed — to therapeutic drug design, according to a "https:\/\/deepmind.google\/discover\/blog\/a-glimpse-of-the-next-generation-of-alphafold\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> on the DeepMind blog, helping to characterize different types of molecular structures important for treating disease.<\/p>\n New capabilities<\/h2>\n The new AlphaFold’s capabilities extend beyond protein prediction.<\/p>\n DeepMind claims that the model can also accurately predict the structures of ligands — molecules that bind to “receptor” proteins and cause changes in how cells communicate — as well as nucleic acids (molecules that contain key genetic information) and post-translational modifications (chemical changes that occur after a protein’s created).<\/p>\n "attachment_2622444\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2622444\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2622444\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp\" alt=\"A protein structure predicted by the latest AlphaFold model.\" width=\"1024\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp 1232w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=150,99 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=300,198 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=768,506 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=680,448 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=1200,791 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/unnamed.webp?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2622444\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> DeepMind<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Predicting protein-ligand structures can be a useful tool in drug discovery, DeepMind notes, as it can help scientists identify and design new molecules that could become drugs.<\/p>\n Currently, pharmaceutical researchers use computer simulations known as “docking methods” to determine how proteins and ligands will interact. Docking methods require specifying a reference protein structure and a suggested position on that structure for the ligand to bind to.<\/p>\n With the latest AlphaFold, however, there’s no need to use a reference protein structure or suggested position. The model can predict proteins that haven’t been “structurally characterized” before, while at the same time simulating how proteins and nucleic acids interact with other molecules — a level of modeling that DeepMind says isn’t possible with today’s docking methods.<\/p>\n "4t9u1\">“Early analysis also shows that our model greatly outperforms [the previous generation of] AlphaFold on some protein structure prediction problems that are relevant for drug discovery, like antibody binding,” DeepMind writes in the post. “Our model\u2019s dramatic leap in performance shows the potential of AI to greatly enhance scientific understanding of the molecular machines that make up the human body.”<\/p>\n The newest AlphaFold isn’t perfect, though.<\/p>\n In a "https:\/\/storage.googleapis.com\/deepmind-media\/DeepMind.com\/Blog\/a-glimpse-of-the-next-generation-of-alphafold\/alphafold_latest_oct2023.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">whitepaper<\/a> detailing the system’s strengths and limitations, researchers at DeepMind and Isomorphic Labs reveal that the system falls short of the best-in-class method for predicting the structures of RNA molecules — the molecules in the body that carry the instructions for making proteins.<\/p>\n Doubtless, both DeepMind and Isomorphic Labs are working to address this.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Nearly five years ago, DeepMind, one of Google’s more prolific AI-centered research labs, debuted AlphaFold, an AI system that can accurately predict the structures of many proteins inside the human body. Since then, DeepMind has improved on the system, releasing an updated and more capable version of AlphaFold — AlphaFold 2 — in 2020. And […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574536,"featured_media":2618210,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"5df8d1e5-5d50-3d88-b8fb-8df1577c93b3","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-31T15:50:11Z","apple_news_api_id":"6932e75a-b78a-4afd-a351-e9d9ccf7f51d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-31T17:54:15Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AaTLnWreKSv2jUenZzPf1HQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577030454],"tags":[14067,210341831,576603353,449555745,1460,576945634],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n useful in drug discovery applications.\" \/>\n "canonical\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/deepminds-latest-alphafold-model-is-more-useful-for-drug-discovery\/\" \/>\n "og:locale\" TechCrunch","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/isomorphic-labs\/#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"BreadcrumbList","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/isomorphic-labs\/#breadcrumb","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"isomorphic labs"}]},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576945634"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=576945634"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576945634"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622389,"date":"2023-10-31T08:50:04","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T15:50:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622389"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:04:55","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:04:55","slug":"united-states-cybersecurity-coalition-deny-ransom-demands","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/united-states-cybersecurity-coalition-deny-ransom-demands\/","title":{"rendered":"US-led cybersecurity coalition vows to not pay hackers’ ransom demands"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The U.S. government and dozens of foreign allies have pledged never to pay ransom demands in a bid to discourage financially motivated hackers and ransomware gangs profiteering from cyberattacks.<\/p>\n The joint pledge was announced during the third annual meeting of the International Counter Ransomware Initiative, or CRI, a U.S.-led cyber coalition that aims to enhance international cooperation to combat the growth of ransomware. The CRI includes 48 countries, as well as the European Union and Interpol, making it the largest cyber partnership in the world.<\/p>\n The first-of-its-kind joint pledge, detailed by U.S. deputy national security advisor Anne Neuberger during a call with reporters on Monday, resulted in dozens of members signing a policy statement declaring that their governments would not pay ransom demands. The pledge stops short of banning companies from making ransom payments, which the U.S. government has long warned could inadvertently create opportunities for further extortion by ransomware gangs, but Neuberger says that the initiative will aim to “counter the illicit finance that underpins the ransomware ecosystem.”<\/p>\n Ransomware attacks remain at "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">an all-time high given\u00a0the majority of victims continue to pay ransoms which fund the hackers<\/a> behind these cyberattacks. Data from blockchain analysis firm "https:\/\/www.chainalysis.com\/blog\/crypto-crime-midyear-2023-update-ransomware-scams\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chainalysis<\/a> shows that victims paid ransomware groups $449 million in the first six months of this year. If this pace continues, the total figure for 2023 could reach almost $900 million, making 2023 the second-most profitable year for ransomware actors after 2021, according to Chainalysis.<\/p>\n Not all of the 48 CRI member governments have yet agreed to the anti-ransom payment pledge, Neuberger said, though it\u2019s not yet known which governments have signed up.<\/p>\n \u201cThis was a really big lift, and we\u2019re in the final throes of getting every last member to sign,\u201d Neuberger said. \u201cBut we’re pretty much there, which is exciting.\u201d<\/p>\n Full details of the joint pledge, which are still being finalized, have not yet been announced. The White House has not yet said how member states will be held accountable to their pledge, or what consequences they face, if any, if they make a ransom payment.<\/p>\n Ransomware and extortion gangs have targeted several governments in recent years, including "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/31\/montenegro-ransomware-attack-embassy-warning\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Montenegro<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/costa-rica-ransomware-attack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Costa Rica<\/a>, as well as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/17\/cisa-iran-hackers-ransomware\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">U.S. government systems<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/03\/us-government-royal-ransomware-advisory\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">critical infrastructure<\/a>. In 2021, U.S. energy giant Colonial Pipeline paid $5 million to hackers who broke in and deployed ransomware. The cyberattack prompted the company to shut down its pipelines, causing "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/30\/the-year-the-tide-turned-on-ransomware\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">major disruptions to gas supplies<\/a> across the U.S. east coast.<\/p>\n During Monday’s call, Neuberger said that ransom payments not only fuel future attacks but also don\u2019t guarantee the safe return of stolen data \u2014 or that all copies have been erased. Data provided to the U.S. government by ransomware negotiators shows that companies with good backups are able to recover \u201cfar more quickly\u201d than companies that pay a ransom.<\/p>\n “Paying a ransom not only encourages ongoing ransomware attacks, it also is not necessarily the fastest way to recover,” said Neuberger. “Do those backups and do the basic cybersecurity practices that we know make a difference.”<\/p>\n The CRI on Tuesday also announced several additional measures designed to improve its members\u2019 ability to fight back against ransomware attacks. This includes a shared denylist, which will include information on digital wallets being used to move ransomware payments and two new information-sharing platforms to help members quickly share data about ransomware operators, their tools and their techniques with their foreign allies.<\/p>\n “If one country is attacked, others can quickly defend against that attack,” Neuberger said on the call with reporters.<\/p>\n Members of the initiative will also use artificial intelligence to analyze blockchains to help identify ransomware payments flowing through cryptocurrency platforms.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ZmFc4M0aAt\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/\">Why ransomware victims can’t stop paying off hackers<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Why ransomware victims can’t stop paying off hackers” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/ransomware-victims-paying-hackers-ransom\/embed\/#?secret=3bUQeZDE9N#?secret=ZmFc4M0aAt\" data-secret=\"ZmFc4M0aAt\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The U.S. government and dozens of foreign allies have pledged never to pay ransom demands in a bid to discourage financially motivated hackers and ransomware gangs profiteering from cyberattacks. The joint pledge was announced during the third annual meeting of the International Counter Ransomware Initiative, or CRI, a U.S.-led cyber coalition that aims to enhance Santiago"},"authors":[133574210],"caption":{"rendered":" WOODBRIDGE, NEW JERSEY – MAY 10: Fuel holding tanks are seen at Colonial Pipeline’s Linden Junction Tank Farm on May 10, 2021 in Woodbridge, New Jersey. Alpharetta, Georgia-based Colonial Pipeline, which has the largest fuel pipeline, was forced to shut down its oil and gas pipeline system on Friday after a ransomware attack that has slowed down the transportation of oil in the eastern U.S. On Sunday, the federal government announced an emergency declaration that extends through June 8th and can be renewed. On Monday, the FBI confirmed that the cyberattack was carried out by DarkSide, a cybercrime gang believed to operate out of Russia. (Photo by Michael M. Alpharetta, Georgia-based Colonial Pipeline, which has the largest fuel pipeline, was forced to shut down its oil and gas pipeline system on Friday after a ransomware attack that has slowed down the transportation of oil in the eastern U.S. On Sunday, the federal government announced an emergency declaration that extends through June 8th and can be renewed. On Monday, the FBI confirmed that the cyberattack was carried out by DarkSide, a cybercrime gang believed to operate out of Russia. (Photo by Michael M. onal-startup-founder\/","title":{"rendered":"How to be an inspirational startup founder"},"content":{"rendered":" "article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n "article__contributor-byline\">\n\t "contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t "byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t "byline__author-name\">Scott Friend<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t "byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t "contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t "_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sfriend37\">\n\t\t\t\t\t "icon icon--x icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t Share on X<\/title>\n\t\t "M 0.16 0.759 L 7.256 10.9 L 0.533 18.759 L 3.174 18.759 L 8.437 12.59 L 12.754 18.759 L 19.664 18.759 L 12.242 8.134 L 18.533 0.759 L 15.934 0.759 L 11.064 6.447 L 7.092 0.759 L 0.16 0.759 Z M 4 2.759 L 6.049 2.759 L 15.826 16.759 L 13.795 16.759 L 4 2.759 Z\" \/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t "contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\t "https:\/\/baincapitalventures.com\/team\/scott-friend\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Scott Friend<\/a> is a partner at "https:\/\/baincapitalventures.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bain Capital Ventures<\/a>, where he brings his experience as a founder in commerce ecosystems to "https:\/\/baincapitalventures.com\/the-head-start-early-stage-startup-guide-for-founders\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">founders at all stages<\/a> across applications, software and commerce.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div> "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">The thing that<\/span> the best and brightest entrepreneurs have in common is their ability to inspire \u2014 their customers, employees and investors.<\/p>\n I\u2019ve worked with top-tier founders like Marc Lore of Jet (sold to Walmart for $3.3 billion in 2016), Brian Long of Attentive Mobile (valued at over $11 billion in 2021) and Jennifer Hyman of Rent the Runway (went public in 2021), who share this power, and they leave all their key stakeholders as excited as they are to tackle their markets.<\/p>\n It\u2019s a common misconception that this ability to inspire is the same thing as charisma. There are many examples of people who are popular and well-liked but lack the ability to rally those around them around a common mission.<\/p>\n For startup founders, particularly in the early stages, the ability to inspire has everything to do with the ability to get others to see the world the way you do. Generally speaking, that means not only articulating a compelling vision of the future that includes a problem you\u2019re trying to solve, but also clearly laying out the concrete gameplan for how you\u2019re going to get there.<\/p>\n This is why inspirational leadership can make all the difference to your early-stage startup, and it\u2019s important to note that it is something to practice, rather than a trait only inherent in some people. In this piece, I\u2019ll explore ways this skill applies to all aspects of company-building and will share insights into how any founder, regardless of personality, can develop this skill for themselves.<\/p>\n Practice articulating your vision<\/h2>\n More than anything, the ability to inspire comes from your own conviction \u2014 in your mission and in your vision. Often, figuring out that vision is less a matter of creation and more an act of remembering: What was the thing that drew you to the life of an entrepreneur in the first place? What\u2019s the singular problem in the universe you believe that you and your team are uniquely capable of solving?<\/p>\n \t "article-block block--pullout block--right\">\n\t\t \n\t\t\tFor startup founders, the ability to inspire has everything to do with the ability to get others to see the world the way you do.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n Once you can clearly and concisely articulate both that problem and your solution, you need to work on the ability to get other people as fired up about the mission as you are. Founders should practice describing their vision in a clear and succinct way, getting their stakeholders to see a future that doesn\u2019t yet exist. It\u2019s a matter of selling not only your mission, but also your confidence in achieving it.<\/p>\n This ability to inspire plays a key role in recruiting, particularly for early-stage startups. Much like "https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/carminegallo\/2016\/11\/12\/how-steve-jobs-and-bill-gates-inspired-john-sculley-to-pursue-the-noble-cause\/?sh=1838591c232b\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Steve Jobs\u2019 legendary call to arms to Pepsi\u2019s John Sculley<\/a>, your ability to recruit the talent you need hinges largely on whether you can get them as excited for the opportunity as you are.<\/p>\n Take it from me: In my own career as an entrepreneur, as co-founder of ProfitLogic, my co-founder and I were faced with a scenario where we were actively scouting an engineer right before his graduation from Harvard\u2019s computer science program. The problem was that he had three other very lucrative offers on the table from brand-name outfits, including Microsoft.<\/p>\n ransomware victims can’t stop paying off hackers"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">In September, MGM<\/span> Resorts was hit by a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/mgm-cyberattack-outage-scattered-spider\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">devastating ransomware attack<\/a>, downing operations at some of its most iconic casino hotels in Las Vegas, including the Bellagio, Mandalay Bay and the Cosmopolitan.<\/p>\n Guests were forced to wait hours to check in after the cyberattack crippled electronic payments, slot machines, ATMs and paid parking systems. The hackers also stole "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/mgm-resorts-admits-hackers-stole-customers-personal-data-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a huge cache of customers’ personal information<\/a> from MGM’s servers.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2023-10-11\/mgm-hackers-waited-for-days-before-issuing-their-ransom-demands\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">MGM declined to pay<\/a> the attackers\u2019 ransom demand to get its systems and data back. The amount of the ransom isn’t yet known, though it\u2019s likely less than the $100 million in profit the company said in a\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/ix?doc=\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/789570\/000119312523251667\/d461062d8k.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">regulatory filing<\/a> it will lose in the aftermath of the cyberattack.<\/p>\n While the MGM cyberattack dominated headlines for weeks, an "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/14\/caesars-entertainment-data-breach-cyberattack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">earlier cyberattack on Caesars Entertainment<\/a> barely made it into the news. That\u2019s largely because the hotel and casino giant paid off the hackers to prevent the disclosure of stolen data in the hope of making the incident go away.<\/p>\n Caesars is by no means alone. According to a survey of hundreds of security leaders "https:\/\/www.splunk.com\/en_us\/newsroom\/press-releases\/2023\/ciso-research-reveals-90-of-organizations-suffered-at-least-one-major-cyber-attack-in-the-last-year-83-report-ransomware-payments.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">published<\/a> by Splunk, some 83% of organizations admitted to paying hackers following a ransomware attack, and more than half paid at least $100,000, either through cyber insurance or a third-party.<\/p>\n Paying is easy, trust is impossible<\/h2>\n Paying the attackers\u2019 ransom \u2014 particularly for large organizations with plenty of cash \u2014 often seems like the easiest and cheapest option to get their networks operational and any stolen data recovered. But there’s no guarantee that paying up will ensure the safe return of stolen data \u2014 or that all copies have been erased. After all, any data stolen by cybercriminals is compromised whether a ransom is paid or not, and you can’t trust a criminal’s word that they actually deleted your data.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/lI9N3ZBrjfI?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n Caesars’ breach stayed largely out of the headlines, but the company’s liability remained largely the same. Caesars was still forced to admit to regulators that it paid a ransom to the hackers who had stolen a copy of Caesars’ loyalty program database, which includes driver licenses and Social Security numbers for a \u201csignificant number of members.\u201d<\/p>\n Even then, Caesars admitted that it \u201ccannot guarantee\u201d that the hackers kept their end of the bargain and actually deleted the data they stole.<\/p>\n Sanctions can still sting<\/h2>\n There\u2019s also a technical hazard in paying a hacker’s ransom. According to "https:\/\/www.cybereason.com\/blog\/ransomware-attacks-by-the-numbers-and-how-to-defend-against-them\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a study by Cybereason<\/a>, 80% of ransomware victims who paid the ransom were hit by a subsequent ransomware attack, with 68% of compromised organizations saying that the second attack came less than a month later and that the hackers demanded a higher ransom.<\/p>\n That\u2019s because when an organization pays a ransom, it solves an immediate problem, but also announces a willingness to pay potentially large sums of money to resolve a crisis.<\/p>\n \u201cThe reason the attacks keep coming is because there’s money on the end for the adversary and they\u2019re actually accomplishing what they’re trying to accomplish,\u201d MK Palmore, former FBI agent and director in Google Cloud’s Office of the CISO, said at "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/26\/ransomware-public-sector-fight-back\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">TechCrunch Disrupt<\/a>. \u201cIf you were to cut off the reward for them at the end I think we would likely see less in the way of attacks,\u201d said Palmore.<\/p>\n Paying a ransom demand is not illegal, though the FBI has long advised companies not to pay, since paying encourages ransomware gangs to continue to target new victims.<\/p>\n But organizations can still find themselves in legal (and criminal) hot water if found paying a ransomware gang sanctioned by the U.S. government. The U.S. Treasury "https:\/\/ofac.treasury.gov\/sanctions-programs-and-country-information\/sanctions-related-to-significant-malicious-cyber-enabled-activities\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">warns<\/a> that paying ransoms to sanctioned hacking and ransomware groups could constitute a violation of U.S. sanctions laws, which can lead to criminal prosecution.<\/p>\n While paying the ransom demand might seem like the easiest and cheapest option, it is likely to cost an organization more in the long run.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"vKDs3QdAwH\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/26\/ransomware-public-sector-fight-back\/\">Why the public sector is an easy target for ransomware<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Why the public sector is an easy target for ransomware” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/26\/ransomware-public-sector-fight-back\/embed\/#?secret=Z4kGysA4Id#?secret=vKDs3QdAwH\" data-secret=\"vKDs3QdAwH\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In September, MGM Resorts was hit by a devastating ransomware attack, downing operations at some of its most iconic casino hotels in Las Vegas, including the Bellagio, Mandalay Bay and the Cosmopolitan. Guests were forced to wait hours to check in after the cyberattack crippled electronic payments, slot machines, ATMs and paid parking systems. The […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574469,"featured_media":2622422,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"7bd030f4-9e14-34e5-9be9-f8f6f4c5efcb","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-31T15:46:39Z","apple_news_api_id":"e5071e31-5504-4e07-a39a-07306ace4f9c","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-31T20:57:49Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A5QceMVUETgejmgcwas5PnA","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[21587494],"tags":[6148720,965824,2311,577134670,192933],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n class=\"yoast-schema-graph\">{\"@context\":\"https:\/\/schema.org\",\"@graph\":[{\"@type\":\"ProfilePage\",\"@id\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/carly-page\/\",\"url\":\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/author\/carly-page\/\",\"name\":\"Carly
